author: Laura Beavis And James Dunlevie
title: Remembering Tasmania's WWII 'Doomed Battalion'
text:
Map: Launceston 7250 
The Tasmanian members of the so-called 'Doomed Battalion' from World War II who did make it out alive would often be unwilling, or unable, to share the stories with their families of what they had seen and done. Photo: Karen Cassidy, Rod Stone and Chris Cassidy (seated) at the 75th anniversary commemoration. (ABC News: Laura Beavis) 
The nickname stems from the impossible task Australia's 2/40th Battalion, made up mostly of Tasmanians, was assigned in February 1942 soon after Japan had entered the war. 
Ill-equipped and undersupplied, the 2/40th were ordered to defend an airfield in Timor against an expected attack, which came on February 20. 
"There were only 919 of them, versus a reported 23,000 Japanese invasion force," Rod Stone, coordinator of the Friends of the 2/40th Battalion, said at a ceremony in Launceston to remember the men. 
After several days of intense fighting, with food and ammunition supplies exhausted, the 2/40th were sent a message by the Japanese commanders; surrender or be bombed out of existence. Photo: A survivor from the 2/40th recovers in Singapore after the war. (Supplied: Australian War Memorial) 
It was on this day, 75 years ago, contact was lost with the 2/40th, as the bulk of the force were taken prisoner, with many sent to work on the infamous Burma Railway . 
"It's of great significance to the families, because a lot of the families only have that one date when they knew the men just couldn't fight on," Mr Stone said. 
"It was a monumental task for them to be sent in the first place, but to be up against those odds was just unbelievable." 
Nearly a third of the battalion never made it home. Only two members are still alive and live in Hobart. 
"The Burma railway has a huge slice of Tasmanian influence in it," Mr Stone said. 
"The younger generation need to be aware of the respect that's due for these men who faced insurmountable odds and held us in very, very good stead for our freedom and our values that we have in society today." 'Need to keep telling their stories' 
Chris Cassidy carried the battalion's flag during today's march, in honour of his father Ronald Cassidy. 
He said he and his siblings had deep respect for what their father had endured, although they had to learn about his experience from his friends. 
"Dad was our hero. What he went through, and the men who went through with him, which they never spoke of much, only from their mates," Mr Cassidy said. 
"They talked about other men, but they wouldn't talk about themselves." Photo: Friends and relatives of 2/40th Battalion at the ceremony to honour the men. (ABC News: Laura Beavis) 
Mr Stone's father was with Mr Cassidy's father Ron on the Burma Railway. He said his dad had nominated Mr Stone as having "saved his life". 
"Our family had no idea ... we all have come to appreciate these men just don't talk about things, they just keep it to themselves, and it was a big surprise to the family." 
Another battalion member's son, Graeme Shields, said his father was also reluctant to speak of his experiences. 
"He was very damaged by it, he came back with war neurosis and he was a broken man, and our family relived the war for 16 years after," Mr Shields said. 
Mr Stone said the 2/40th's descendants need to keep telling their stories. 
"They were brutal stories, but they are just stories of great perseverance and great trials under extreme pressure."
